ЁЯРп
Rise of the Tiger

The Chola dynasty, whose symbol was the 'Tiger', was one of the ancient and longest-ruling dynasties of South India. Their core region was the fertile delta of the Kaveri River, known as 'Cholamandalam' (Coromandel). Their early capital was Uraiyur, famous for its cotton textiles, and later the historic port city of Puhar (Kaveripattinam) became the capital.

ЁЯМК
Maritime Empire and Trade

The Cholas were renowned for their naval power. They succeeded in extending their influence not only over South India but also over Sri Lanka, the Maldives, and Southeast Asia (Srivijaya). Kaveripattinam was a bustling port where Roman, Arab, and Chinese merchants frequented. The Sangam poem 'Pattinaappalai' provides a detailed account of the prosperity and commerce of this city.

ЁЯПЧя╕П
Architecture and Administration

The Cholas were great patrons of art and architecture. The medieval Cholas built magnificent granite temples like the Brihadeeswara Temple in Thanjavur. Their administration was highly organized, featuring a unique and democratic system of local self-governance (village assemblies), details of which are found in the Uttaramerur inscriptions.
